title: Pharrell Williams ‘embarrassed’ by controversial Blurred Lines lyrics
text:
The singer Pharrell Williams has claimed that he is now “embarrassed” by his controversial 2013 song Blurred Lines.

In an interview with US GQ, Williams says that he was “born in a different era, where the rules of the matrix at that time allowed a lot of things that would never fly today”.

He goes on to criticise the “chauvinist culture” into which Blurred Lines fitted.

The song, recorded with musicians Robin Thicke and T.I., sparked a debate around sexual consent and “rape culture” on account of its lyrics, which included lines such as “I hate these blurred lines / I know you want it”.

It was banned by student unions in several universities across Britain and America, although it became the best-selling single of 2013, with 14.8 million copies sold.

“I realised,” Williams says in the interview, “that there are men who use that same language when taking advantage of a woman, and it doesn’t matter that that’s not my behavior… It just matters how it affects women.”
description: The singer Pharrell Williams has claimed that he is now “embarrassed” by his controversial 2013 song Blurred Lines.
